messageBody:
On Tue, 2001-08-21 at 02:03, Parag Shetye wrote:

A Growing Problem

The typical way of handling test cases in JUnit is to create a class
with methods beginning with "test". For example, we could create the
methods testNullAccount() and testEmptyAccount() to handle cases where
the account object is null and empty, respectively.

That is THE way to do it.

This approach is
satisfactory for a few test cases, but what if the number of test cases
grows to 50 or even 500?

You shouldn't have this many tests in a single TestCase. You should
have many TestCases. As a guide, I create a new TestCase whenever: a) I
am going to be driving the development of a new class, or b) I need a
different fixture (case "a" generally is a specialy case of this
anyway).

You might work around this limitation by placing all test cases and
assert statements sequentially inside a single method.

Bad idea. You loose a lot of the intent. The method names should
communicate exactly what is being tested. Further, the idea to strive
for (in theory anyway) is to have a single assert in each method. That
keeps the tests small, focused, and (as a result) understandable.

Furthermore, when you are writing a test, start with the assert (what is
being tested) then build up the structure needed to get to the point
that that can be tested (what has to be in place for that to be
tested). Refactor into a fixture as require/appropriate.

Finally, read Kent's book which will be on shelves shortly (drafts are
in the file area of the TDD yahoo group). Then read my book which
should be on shelves early next year. If you read German, get Frank
Westphal's book on TDD which will be out about then as well (English
translation to follow). I also encourage you to subscribe (free) to the
TDD edition of The Coad Letter which I edit/write
(www.thecoadletter.com)

You can also take a course on TDD. I believe Industrial Logic offers a
TDD workshop (their site seems to be down as I write, so I can't
confirm) and we will be as well.

This approach
suffers from two limitations. The first limitation is the need to
replicate the test code for every test case. Even if you have only two
or three lines of code per test case, the size of the method will
mushroom and become hard to maintain (and read).

This is a very bad approach. You loose most of the utility of the
practice. All that you are left with are tests.
